author: By Anna Kodé
title: Judd or Dud: Can You Tell the Difference?
description: It’s not that easy to tell fake Donald Judd furniture from the real thing. See if you can do a better job than Kim Kardashian.
content: “If you guys are furniture people, because I’ve really gotten into furniture lately,” Kim Kardashian said in a YouTube video, gesturing toward a large wooden table and set of chairs, “these Donald Judd tables are really amazing and totally blend in with the seats.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Omar Draws Criticism for Suggesting Some Jewish Students Are ‘Pro-Genocide’
description: Representative Ilhan Omar made the comments at Columbia University, where her daughter was among the students arrested protesting against Israel’s actions in Gaza. The protests have drawn visits by leaders across the political spectrum.
content: Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota, whose daughter was among the students arrested at a Columbia University protest encampment against Israel’s actions in Gaza, suggested while visiting the protesters on campus last week that some Jewish students supported genocide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lionel Shriver
title: What Are Americans So Ticked Off About, Anyway?
description: In “The Age of Grievance,” the New York Times opinion writer Frank Bruni chronicles the nation’s descent into constant kvetching.
content: While conceding that many people have legitimate beefs, the New York Times opinion writer Frank Bruni portrays the contemporary United States in “The Age of Grievance” as consumed by a corrosive resentment on both ends of the political spectrum, driving its poles further apart and rewarding hyperbole, bitterness, acrimony and self-pity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: A Return to New York and, Finally, an Apartment She Can Afford
description: After moving 10 times in 10 years, a woman found that a little luck was the best companion for a lot of hard work. She won a studio in a lottery on her fifth try.
content: Tanzania Hughie had a vision. “I was going to come back to New York, get a job and live in a beautiful place,” she said. “That did not happen right away.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Museums to Visit in California This Year
description: A special section of The New York Times on museums highlights art across the state.
content: Happy Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: TikTok Star Is Killed in Third Death of Social Media Influencer in Iraq
description: The shooting of Ghufran Mahdi Sawadi, known online as Um Fahad, comes amid tightening laws and increasingly conservative attitudes in the country.
content: It took less than 46 seconds for the helmeted assassin to pull over his motorcycle, walk to the driver’s side of the S.U.V., yank open the door and fire his handgun four times, killing one of Iraq’s most prominent TikTok personalities, a 30-year-old woman whose name on social media was Um Fahad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: How ‘History and Tradition’ Rulings Are Changing American Law
description: A new legal standard is gaining traction among conservative judges — one that might turn back the clock on drag shows, gun restrictions and more.
content: In November 2022, a group of L.G.B.T.Q. students at West Texas A&M University started planning a drag show for the following spring. They wanted to raise money for suicide prevention and stand up for queer self-expression at a time when conservatives in Texas, in the name of protecting children, were mobilizing to shut drag shows down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Student Protest Is an Essential Part of Education
description: Student protests at their core are really an extension of education by other means.
content: Anyone who was at Columbia University in the spring of 1968 cannot help but see a reprise of those stormy, fateful and thrilling days in what is happening on the Morningside Heights campus today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: How Supplement Stores Are Trying to Tap Into the Ozempic Boom
description: GNC and the Vitamin Shoppe are redesigning displays and taking other steps to appeal to people who are taking or are interested in drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy.
content: As diabetes and weight-loss drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy took off in the last few years, many people turned away from established diet and nutrition products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Edward Wong, Adam Rasgon and Eric Nagourney
title: Hope Rises for New Talks on Gaza Cease-fire as Israel Scales Back Demands
description: Israel reduced the initial number of hostages it wants released to 33. If Hamas agrees to attend, negotiations on a cease-fire could resume in Cairo this week.
content: Israeli negotiators, offering a hint of hope for negotiations over a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, have reduced the number of hostages they want Hamas to release during the first phase of a truce, three Israeli officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 17 New Books Coming in May
description: New novels from R.O. Kwon, Kevin Kwan and Miranda July; a reappraisal of Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy; memoirs from Brittney Griner and Kathleen Hanna — and more.
content: Once called “the Julia Child of Chinese cooking,” Fu Pei-Mei taught generations of Taiwanese people to cook through her long-running TV show and many cookbooks. King presents not just a biography of an indomitable woman, but a portrait of how cultures eat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mia Leimkuhler
title: A Quick Fish Recipe That Covers All the Bases
description: Made with mild white-fleshed fish, bacon and mushrooms, Melissa Clark’s new dish is fast, flavorful and good for the fishy-fish averse.
content: Hello and “happy” Monday! I’m filling in for Melissa today, so it feels only right to kick things off with her new recipe for creamy fish with mushrooms and bacon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 4 Zebras Broke Free on a Highway. A Rodeo Clown Stepped In.
description: One zebra was still on the loose, after it and three others escaped a trailer in North Bend, Wash. Dozens of people scrambled to help and corralled some of the animals.
content: Four zebras escaped from a trailer on a highway exit in Washington State on Sunday, leading dozens of residents, police officers and volunteers to join in an effort to corral them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: They Shoot Owls in California, Don’t They?
description: An audacious federal plan to protect the spotted owl would eradicate hundreds of thousands of barred owls in the coming years.
content: In the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest, the northern spotted owl, a rare and fragile subspecies of spotted owl, is being muscled out of its limited habitat by the barred owl, its larger and more ornery northeastern cousin. The opportunistic barred owl has been moving in on spotted owl turf for more than half a century, competing with the locals for food and space, outnumbering, out-reproducing and inevitably chasing them out of their nesting spots. Barred owls have also emerged as a threat to the California spotted owl, a closely related subspecies in the Sierra Nevada and the mountains of coastal and Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Gérard Depardieu Ordered to Stand Trial in Sexual Assault Case
description: The actor, who has become a #MeToo flashpoint in France, will be tried in October over allegations that he sexually assaulted two women during a 2021 film shoot.
content: Gérard Depardieu was ordered on Monday to stand trial on criminal charges that he sexually assaulted two women during a 2021 film shoot in France, deepening the French actor’s legal woes and further tarnishing his global reputation as he faces a growing number of accusations of sexual violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Delay, Delay, Delay
description: How Donald Trump has slowed the cases against him.
content: It now seems likely that Donald Trump will be able to run for president this year without having faced any legal penalties for his effort to overturn the last presidential election. To many of his supporters, of course, this outcome is just. But it is also striking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mohamed Ahmed and Emma Bubola
title: Flash Floods Kill at Least 45 in Kenya
description: Heavy rains have been pounding parts of East Africa for weeks, and the flooding has killed hundreds of people in recent days.
content: Flash floods and a landslide sent a deluge of muddy water over a Kenyan village early Monday, killing at least 45 people, as torrential rains continued to pound East Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: grueling
description: This word has appeared in 380 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word grueling has appeared in 380 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 19 in “F.A.A. Will Require More Rest for Air Traffic Controllers” by Sydney Ember:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.3 Million Homes in California
description: A 1926 Spanish-style home in Pasadena, a five-bedroom retreat in Lake Arrowhead and a midcentury ranch house in La Mesa.
content: This house, which is on the market for the first time in 40 years, is in a historic district in the Casa Grande neighborhood, where many of the homes date to the early 20th century. It is about a mile from Pasadena High School and Victory Park, which has baseball fields and a recreation center with an indoor gym. The Rose Bowl Stadium and the Los Angeles County Arboretum, in Arcadia, are about 10 minutes away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Matt Gaetz Faces Last-Minute Challenger in Republican Primary
description: The Florida representative will face off against Aaron Dimmock, a retired Navy officer and aviator.
content: Aaron Dimmock, a retired Navy officer and aviator, has entered the Republican primary to challenge Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida — jumping into the race hours before a filing deadline last Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Student Protester Is Suspended After Anti-Zionist Video
description: Khymani James, a Columbia University student, was barred from campus after his January video resurfaced online last week.
content: Columbia University officials are now weighing what final disciplinary action to take against a student leader of the pro-Palestinian movement after an inflammatory video resurfaced in which the student said “Zionists don’t deserve to live.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: With Paramount in Chaos and Its Future Uncertain, Its Chief Steps Down
description: Bob Bakish was once a staunch ally of Shari Redstone, Paramount’s controlling shareholder. His departure comes as the company considers a major merger.
content: Shari Redstone, the controlling shareholder of Paramount, has tried to resist the erosion of her media empire over the last decade as she confronted the death of cable TV, the rise of streaming and even a failed boardroom coup from a longtime ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Koch Group Attacks Biden on the Economy, Hoping to Engage Latino Voters
description: Libre, an arm of the conservative network, is set to spend millions of dollars on outreach and advertising as Republicans seek to expand inroads with Hispanic voters.
content: The Libre Initiative, part of the political network created by the billionaire industrialist Koch brothers, on Monday will unveil a seven-figure voter engagement effort and ad campaign targeting members of Congress who have supported what it calls President Biden’s “punitive economic policies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Team Sees Narrow Window for Deal on Cease-Fire and Hostages in Gaza
description: A number of factors have converged to make this a moment when the president might be able to break through the stalemate, advisers say. But their optimism has been dashed before.
content: President Biden and his national security team see a narrow window to finally seal an agreement that would at least temporarily halt the war in Gaza and possibly end it for good even as they deflect pressure from college campus protests to abandon Israel in its fight against Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Wu
title: When It Comes to TikTok, the World’s Democracies Have Played the Sucker for Far Too Long
description: With its TikTok bill, Congress sent a message to the world: You cannot disregard basic internet norms and expect to be treated like any other country.
content: China’s violations of human rights and the basic norms of internet freedom are blatant and obvious. This month, with little fanfare, the country ordered Apple to block downloads of WhatsApp, Threads and Signal within its borders. It already prevents citizens from connecting to dozens of other providers of information, including this newspaper and Wikipedia, and for years, it has aggressively surveilled journalists and dissidents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: A Starry Cast Navigates ‘Uncle Vanya’ and ‘Every Emotion Under the Sun’
description: Steve Carell, William Jackson Harper, Alison Pill and Anika Noni Rose discuss the new translation of Chekhov that brought them to the farm.
content: Broadway shows usually come with a back story about the yearslong slog it took to get them there. Not so with Heidi Schreck’s new translation of Chekhov’s “Uncle Vanya,” which arrived at Lincoln Center Theater’s Vivian Beaumont Theater not even 12 months after its inception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Skydance Offers Paramount a Deal Sweetener: A $3 Billion Cash Infusion
description: The terms of the new deal would provide Paramount shareholders with an investment to pay down debt and buy back stock.
content: With the fate of Paramount hanging in the balance, its leading suitor has just upped the ante.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: The Aggressive and Expensive Legal Team Defending Mayor Adams
description: With Mayor Eric Adams and his top aides facing several investigations, he is amassing a team of high-powered lawyers paid by his donors and city taxpayers.
content: Not long after Eric Adams became the mayor of New York City, he quickly rewarded a cadre of loyalists with plum jobs in his administration. Now Mr. Adams is casting favor upon a new set of people looking out for his interests: defense lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Philips Settles CPAP Breathing Device Lawsuits for $1.1 Billion
description: Thousands of people with sleep apnea and other illnesses had sued the company, claiming flawed devices were harming them.
content: Philips Respironics has reached a $1.1 billion settlement over claims that people who used their CPAP and other breathing devices were harmed by noxious gasses and flecks of foam that lodged in their airways, sometimes for years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Stock
title: Can a Sound Bath Wash Away Your Worries?
description: We asked experts about the health benefits of listening to gongs, chimes and crystal bowls.
content: As the sun set over the Pacific Ocean, the beach cool against my back, a voice invited me to scan my body for feelings of powerlessness. “Then breathe in that area to help it release,” said Sara Sofia Bousiali, the leader of the evening’s sound bath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Election Deniers Are Still Shaping Arizona Politics
description: There have been few political consequences for many Republicans accused of helping Trump try to overturn the 2020 election.
content: Two years ago, a group of election deniers ran for office in Arizona, with Kari Lake’s campaign for governor topping the ticket. When many of them lost, it seemed like a convincing rebuke of the conspiracy theory-steeped Republicans who wanted to control the levers of electoral power in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: ‘Ash’ Review: A Nobel Prize-Winner Confronts Environmental Collapse
description: Elfriede Jelinek’s latest play deals with collective calamity and individual grief, but is let down by a chaotic production.
content: Twenty years ago, when the Austrian writer Elfriede Jelinek received the Nobel Prize in Literature it was a surprise that the award had gone to an author who was barely known outside the German-speaking world. It set off a scandal, too. A juror from the academy that makes the decision resigned, calling Jelinek’s work “unenjoyable, violent pornography.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Coleman and Lola Fadulu
title: N.Y.U. Says It Will Discipline Students Who Remain in Encampment
description: The university had set a noon deadline for an end to overnight stays at the site, but students remained there on Monday afternoon.
content: New York University officials will move to discipline student demonstrators who remain in a pro-Palestinian encampment on campus, the university announced in a statement on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Love, War and the Refugee Crisis, Set to the Music of Sting
description: In “Message in a Bottle,” a dance show opening at City Center, Sting’s songbook helps tell the story of a family fleeing conflict.
content: When the choreographer Kate Prince set out several years ago to create a dance show based on the music of Sting, she was unsure what story she might be able to tell using his varied songbook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 323
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: A D.A. Was Caught Speeding. Her Outburst Earned Her More Than a Ticket.
description: Sandra Doorley, the district attorney of Monroe County, N.Y., refused to pull over and responded angrily to the officer who confronted her, body camera footage showed. Now she faces calls to resign.
content: It was 5:30 p.m. last Monday in Webster, N.Y., a Rochester suburb, when Police Officer Cameron Crisafulli noticed an S.U.V. being driven 20 miles per hour over the speed limit on Phillips Road.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: As the U.K. Tries Moving Asylum Seekers Offshore, Ireland Pushes Back
description: The Irish government said it was drafting emergency legislation to return asylum seekers to Britain, after seeing a surge of people leaving there for sanctuary in Ireland.
content: Britain’s newly ratified plan to put asylum seekers on one-way flights to Rwanda has drawn objections from human rights groups, British and European courts, the House of Lords and even some members of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s Conservative Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage, Rob Szypko, Carlos Prieto, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Ben Calhoun, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Diane Wong, Rowan Niemisto and Chris Wood
title: Trump 2.0: What a Second Trump Presidency Would Bring
description: On the campaign trail, Donald Trump has signaled that a second term would be more radical and vindictive than his first one.
content: In a special series leading up to Election Day, “The Daily” will explore what a second Trump presidency would look like, and what it could mean for American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Surprise Tactics and Legal Threats: Inside R.F.K. Jr.’s Ballot Access Fight
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s effort to get on the ballot in 50 states has already cost millions, federal campaign finance records show.
content: As Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s independent presidential campaign mounts a bruising state-by-state battle for ballot access, he has often credited enthusiastic volunteers and grass-roots backers with driving the effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida Abortion Ban to Take Effect, Cutting Off Major Access Point
description: The state has dozens of clinics that serve tens of thousands of women a year, including from across the Southeast. The six-week ban will require most to travel much farther.
content: Florida has long played a significant role in the American abortion landscape, with dozens of clinics providing the procedure to tens of thousands of residents a year while also taking in patients from across the Southeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Jeffries’s Hint of a Lifeline Bolstered Johnson on Ukraine. Will He Need It?
description: The House Democratic leader has suggested his members would protect Speaker Mike Johnson if right-wing Republicans tried to oust him over Ukraine aid, strengthening the speaker’s hand.
content: When Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the House Democratic leader, was in Munich in mid-February for the annual international security conference, Representative Michael R. Turner, the Ohio Republican and chairman of the Intelligence Committee, quietly sought him out with a request.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Environmental Prize Highlights Work to Keep Fossil Fuels at Bay
description: Around the world, grass-roots organizers and Indigenous communities are taking proposed coal, oil and gas projects to court — and winning.
content: New coal mines continue to open each year, and oil and gas companies are still exploring new parts of the world. But increasingly, people — especially Indigenous communities — are saying no to new fossil fuel developments on their land and using courts and legislatures to deliver the message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy, Kellen Browning and Michael Wines
title: With Abortion and the Border, Arizona Becomes a 2024 Political Hothouse
description: A battle over abortion bans and criminal charges against allies of former President Donald J. Trump continue to raise the state’s election-year profile.
content: To see the battle lines over Arizona’s political future, head to a patch of dirt along the Carefree Highway on the edge of Phoenix, where the state’s big ambitions and bitter grievances are separated by a wire fence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Roiphe
title: I Was an Attorney at the D.A.’s Office. This Is What the Trump Case Is Really About.
description: Boring as it may sound, it is a case about business integrity.
content: Now that the lawyers are laying out their respective theories of the case in the criminal prosecution of Donald Trump in New York, it would be understandable if people’s heads are spinning. The defense lawyers claimed this is a case about hush money as a legitimate tool in democratic elections, while the prosecutors insisted it is about “a criminal scheme to corrupt the 2016 presidential election.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Shteamer
title: Jazz Saved the Bassist Luke Stewart. Now He’s Working to Rescue Others.
description: Stewart’s many projects — Silt Trio, Irreversible Entanglements, Blacks’ Myths and others — make strong statements and foster community. A new LP is out Friday.
content: On a Sunday afternoon in March, Luke Stewart — a bassist and composer who has gradually emerged as a galvanic force in the contemporary jazz vanguard — stood at the corner of Pine and Broadway, in Manhattan’s Financial District, running down some local history. He pointed across the street, where the American Stock Exchange sat next to Trinity Church, and noted our proximity to the former site of New York’s municipal slave market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: How Rachel Khong Conjures Worlds, in Her Books and Beyond
description: She wrote her much-anticipated second novel, “Real Americans,” while also creating the Ruby, a co-working collective for writers and other artists.
content: By the time Rachel Khong was finishing her latest novel, “Real Americans,” in 2022, interest in the book was so high that it sparked a 17-way bidding war between many of the country’s top publishing houses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Campus Protests: Voices From Columbia, Barnard and Beyond
description: Sampling the outpouring of responses to the continuing protests on college campuses. Also: The Trump criminal cases; Trump, Pence and abortion.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Universities Face an Urgent Question: What Makes a Protest Antisemitic?
description: Pro-Palestinian student activists say their movement is anti-Zionist but not antisemitic. It is not a distinction that everyone accepts.
content: In a video shared widely online, a leader of the pro-Palestinian student movement at Columbia University stands near the center of a lawn on the campus and calls out, “We have Zionists who have entered the camp.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 29, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 29, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Catfish’ and ‘Welcome to Wrexham’
description: The show, hosted by Nev Schulman and Kamie Crawford, begins its ninth season on MTV. Ryan Reynolds and Rob McElhenney’s soccer series on FX is back for Season 3.
content: For those like me who still haven’t cut the cord, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, April 29-May 5. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israel Softened Its Demands in Cease-Fire Negotiations
description: Also, Russian forces advance in Ukraine before U.S. aid arrives. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Israeli officials said today that they had reduced the number of hostages they were asking Hamas to free in exchange for a temporary cease-fire in the war in Gaza. The new stance raised expectations that the two sides might be edging closer to agreeing on their first truce in five months. A new round of cease-fire negotiations could begin as soon as tomorrow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: A Peek Inside the Brains of ‘Super-Agers’
description: New research explores why some octogenarians have exceptional memories.
content: When it comes to aging, we tend to assume that cognition gets worse as we get older. Our thoughts may slow down or become confused, or we may start to forget things, like the name of our high school English teacher or what we meant to buy at the grocery store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Young, Cool, Coddled and Raised on the Internet
description: The best stories in Honor Levy’s “My First Book” capture the quiet desperation of today’s smart set. But there is such a thing as publishing too soon.
content: “Thank God I won’t have to deal with the internet.” According to Bruce Jay Friedman, those were the last words his friend Mario Puzo ever said to him. We forget — or at least I do — how many writers from the last century made it into the age of email. Muriel Spark lived long enough to write a series of online diaries for Slate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: PEN America Has Stood by Authors. They Should Stand by PEN.
description: PEN America needs to ensure more than one point of view is heard on even the most contentious issue.
content: All strong institutions stand to benefit from internal dissent and external pressures. But too often, recent efforts to reform institutions have meant reconstituting them in ways that distort or fundamentally undermine their core mission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: What to Know: First Trial in Alleged Coup Plot in Germany Begins
description: Three trials this spring are centered on the Reichsbürger movement. Some of its members say the modern German state is actually a corporation run by shadowy bureaucrats.
content: Nearly a year and a half after police and intelligence officers in Germany uncovered a plot to overthrow the country’s government and replace its chancellor, the first of three trials in the sprawling case began on Monday in Stuttgart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Korsha Wilson, Brett Anderson, Melissa Clark, Tanya Sichynsky and Nikita Richardson
title: The 25 Best Restaurants in Washington, D.C. Right Now
description: The food scene in and around the nation’s capital is vibrant these days, with Italian, Ethiopian, Salvadoran and more. Comments are open.
content: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free dishes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Covid Class Denied Second Chance at Normal Senior Year
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 29, 2024.
content: “It’s a very big hit to morale for the exact class that felt like they lost their high school graduation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Hamas Fires Rockets Into Israel from Lebanon
description: The launches, nearly all of which Israel shot down, were an apparent attempt by the group to show it remains a threat even as the war has degraded its military capabilities in Gaza.
content: Hamas’s military wing said on Monday that it had launched a salvo of rockets from Lebanon into northern Israel, an apparent attempt by the group to signal that it is still capable of striking within Israel’s borders even as it studies the latest proposal for a cease-fire in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neelam Bohra and J. David Goodman
title: New Round of Arrests at University of Texas as Protesters Defy Governor
description: Days after a crackdown on pro-Palestinian protesters, at least 50 people were arrested after new tents were erected on the Austin campus.
content: Police officers from the University of Texas at Austin and state troopers in riot gear swept in on Monday to clear a small number of tents erected on campus by pro-Palestinian protesters, arresting dozens of people and briefly deploying pepper spray against demonstrators who were chanting “Off our campus!” and trying to block law enforcement vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Stowaway Cat Gets From Utah to California in Amazon Returns Package
description: Galena, a 6-year-old shorthair, was found in an Amazon warehouse a week after she climbed into a 3-by-3-foot cardboard box at her owner’s home.
content: When Carrie Clark got a phone call on April 17 from a veterinarian in California informing her that her cat, which had vanished from her Utah home a week earlier, had been found some 500 miles away, her first reaction was disbelief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Stuber
title: 9 Places to See the Summer Olympics Without Setting Foot in Paris
description: You may have trouble finding accommodations or tickets to events in Paris, but other destinations around France are hosting sports like soccer, sailing, basketball and surfing.
content: For sports fans, Paris will be the center of the universe this summer — and with 15 million Olympic and Paralympic visitors expected, it will feel like it, with crowds and high prices. But Paris isn’t the only Olympic site in France: Nine destinations outside the metro region are also hosting events, giving travelers a way to catch some action without getting caught up in the crush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Can Nonprofit News Save the South From Itself?
description: If old school public-service journalism can make it anywhere, it can make it here.
content: When I moved here in 1987, Nashville had two daily newspapers: a morning paper, The Tennessean, whose editorial page leaned left; and an evening paper, The Nashville Banner, whose editorial page leaned right. I still subscribe to The Tennessean, but The Banner is long gone. In 1998, The Tennessean bought its longtime competitor and shut it down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Class of 2024, It’s Not in Your Head: The Job Market Is Tough
description: College-level jobs still pay a lot more overall, but not every grad can get one.
content: Here is a brutal fact for the college class of 2024: There aren’t enough college-level jobs out there for all of you. Some of you will snag them. Others will have to settle for jobs that don’t require a college education. And history shows that many of those who start out in a job that doesn’t require a college education are still toiling in that kind of job a decade later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Blue Ivy Carter to Join Beyoncé in ‘Mufasa: The Lion King’
description: Beyoncé’s 12-year-old daughter will make her feature film debut as Kiara, Nala and Simba’s daughter, in a prequel to the 2019 hit.
content: Blue Ivy Carter will be joining her mother, Beyoncé Knowles-Carter, in the movie musical “Mufasa: The Lion King,” which is expected in theaters in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Physical Fitness Linked to Better Mental Health in Young People
description: A new study bolsters existing research suggesting that exercise can protect against anxiety, depression and attention challenges.
content: Physical fitness among children and adolescents may protect against developing depressive symptoms, anxiety and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, according to a study published on Monday in JAMA Pediatrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández and James Estrin
title: A Student Orchestra Shouts ‘Mambo!’ and Meets Gustavo Dudamel
description: Our photographer followed 95 young musicians for six days as they prepared to perform with Dudamel, the next music director of the New York Philharmonic.
content: The student musicians, dressed in jeans, T-shirts and hooded sweatshirts, were rehearsing an excerpt from “West Side Story” in a high school auditorium one recent afternoon. Then, as the trumpets blared and the timpani went wild, a voice broke out from the conductor’s podium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David C. Adams
title: In a Communist Stronghold, Capitalists Become an Economic Lifeline
description: Cuba’s Communist revolution took aim at private businesses, making them largely illegal. Today, they are proliferating, while the socialist economy craters.
content: A modern grocery store whose shelves are packed with everything from pasta to wine fills a spot in central Havana once occupied by a drab state-owned flower shop, its ceilings and walls repaired and repainted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Amid Cases on Abortion and Trump, Roberts Reflects on Supreme Court’s Work
description: Oral arguments serve a crucial role at the Supreme Court, Chief Justice John Roberts said last week at Georgetown University. But they are not always what they seem.
content: Just hours after the Supreme Court heard arguments last week in an important abortion case and the day before it considered whether former President Donald J. Trump must face trial on charges that he plotted to subvert the 2020 election, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. took a break to share some timely reflections on the role of oral arguments in the court’s work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and Karl Russell
title: A Strong U.S. Dollar Weighs on the World
description: Two-thirds of the roughly 150 currencies have weakened against the dollar, whose strength stems from high interest rates because of stubborn inflation.
content: Every major currency in the world has fallen against the U.S. dollar this year, an unusually broad shift with the potential for serious consequences across the global economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Columbia Begins to Suspend Student Protesters
description: University officials gave the pro-Palestinian demonstrators a 2 p.m. deadline and threatened to suspend them if they did not leave.
content: Columbia University announced Monday evening that it had begun to suspend students who had failed to leave a pro-Palestinian encampment by a 2 p.m. deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Rachel Chaundler
title: After Mulling Resignation, Spain’s Leader Says He’ll Stay On
description: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez, a progressive with a reputation as a wily survivor, had considered stepping down over corruption accusations against his wife that he says are a smear.
content: Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez of Spain declared on Monday that he would not resign, nearly a week after publicly raising the possibility in response to corruption accusations against his wife that he and other officials denounced as a smear campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken Meets With Arab Officials to Discuss Gaza and Postwar Plans
description: “The only thing standing between the people of Gaza and a cease-fire is Hamas,” said Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken spoke with Arab officials on Monday in Saudi Arabia about the war between Israel and Hamas and the difficult issues it has created, from humanitarian aid to hostages. Mr. Blinken plans to travel to Jordan and Israel on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: Hope Rises for New Cease-Fire Talks
description: Also, Russia advances in eastern Ukraine.
content: Negotiations for a pause in the fighting between Israel and Hamas could restart as soon as today, officials said. A mid-level Israeli delegation is planning to fly to Cairo for new talks mediated by Egypt, but only if Hamas also agrees to attend, Israeli officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Katie Robertson
title: Right-Wing Network Retracts False Story About Key Witness in Trump Trial
description: Michael D. Cohen’s lawyers took on OAN over the false story. The settlement came as right-wing news outlets face a barrage of defamation suits.
content: One America News, a right-wing cable news network, on Monday retracted a report claiming that Donald J. Trump’s former fixer had been the person who actually had an affair with the porn star whose claims of a sexual relationship with Mr. Trump are key to his criminal trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gish Jen
title: This Isn’t the China I Remember
description: Chinese pride and triumphalism have given way to malaise in the post-Covid era.
content: In 1979 my mother pulled out a Band-Aid in a Nanjing hospital. The nurses clustered around it, amazed. “The West has everything!” they said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Inflation Is Stubborn. Is the Federal Budget Deficit Making It Worse?
description: Economists are divided over whether the growing amount of federal borrowing is fueling demand and driving up prices.
content: A crucial question is hanging over the American economy and the fall presidential election: Why are consumer prices still growing uncomfortably fast, even after a sustained campaign by the Federal Reserve to slow the economy by raising interest rates?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: After Looking for Love on TV, a ‘Bachelor’ Finds His Wife on Instagram
description: When Natalie Joy sent Nick Viall a direct message in 2019, she said she had no idea about his run on reality TV. About a year after meeting in person, their casual arrangement got serious.
content: Nick Joseph Viall is used to his dating life being on public display. From 2014 to 2017, he appeared in four seasons of the “Bachelor” franchise: two seasons of “The Bachelorette,” one season of “Bachelor in Paradise” and, finally, “The Bachelor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian M. Rosenthal and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: Pennsylvania Hospital Suspends Its Liver Transplant Program
description: The move by the Penn State Health Milton S. Hershey Medical Center was the second time this month that a hospital has taken this rare step.
content: A major Pennsylvania hospital shut down its liver transplant program last week, becoming the second medical center this month to take such an unusual step.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Are We All Really Supposed to Wear Cargo Pants?
description: A reader tries to square the style’s enduring appeal with her own reluctance to wear them.
content: Once upon a time cargo pants, otherwise known as “the military’s greatest fashion contribution,” were created to fulfill a very specific function: allowing soldiers to carry crucial tools (or cargo). Invented by the British military in 1938 as part of the new Battle Dress Uniform, cargo pants included a field dressing pocket on the side of the right hip for emergency first aid and a map pocket just above the left knee for navigation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Edward Wong, Nicholas Nehamas, David C. Adams, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and James Shield
title: The Latest Push for a Gaza Pause, and Crackdowns on College Protests
description: Plus, a debate about killing owls.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Should Be Done About the Gender Pay Gap in Sports?
description: Caitlin Clark’s rookie salary in the W.N.B.A. is a fraction of the multimillion dollar contract that Victor Wembanyama signed last year.
content: Caitlin Clark, the electrifying basketball point guard for the University of Iowa, ended an extraordinary, record-breaking year on a high note when she was selected first in the W.N.B.A. draft on April 15.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift’s ‘Tortured Poets’ Breaks Records With Blockbuster Debut
description: Only the Beatles have more No. 1 LPs now: The pop superstar reigns atop the Billboard 200 for the 14th time with the equivalent of 2.6 million album sales.
content: There was never any doubt that Taylor Swift’s latest release, “The Tortured Poets Department,” was going to be big. The question was just how big.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Nico Grant
title: Friends From the Old Neighborhood Turn Rivals in Big Tech’s A.I. Race
description: Demis Hassabis and Mustafa Suleyman, who both grew up in London, feared a corporate rush to build artificial intelligence. Now they’re driving that competition at Google and Microsoft.
content: Mustafa Suleyman grew up in subsidized housing in one of London’s roughest areas. His father, a Syrian immigrant, drove a taxi. His mother was a nurse with the National Health Service. When the prestigious Queen Elizabeth’s School accepted him at the age of 11, the family moved into a safer, leafier neighborhood a few miles north.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: The Tony Nominations Are Tomorrow. Here’s What to Expect.
description: The contenders from a crowded season will be announced by Jesse Tyler Ferguson and Renée Elise Goldsberry.
content: At a time when Broadway is overflowing with plays and musicals but could use more ticket buyers, this season’s Tony Award nominations will be announced on Tuesday, offering a boost to some shows and dashing the hopes of others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher and Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Reaches Deals in China on Self-Driving Cars
description: Elon Musk met with the country’s premier, a longtime Tesla ally, and secured regulatory nods and a necessary partnership with a Chinese tech company.
content: Tesla has concluded a series of arrangements with regulators and a Chinese artificial intelligence company during a quick trip to Beijing on Sunday and Monday by Elon Musk, the carmaker’s chief executive, potentially clearing the way for the company to offer its most advanced self-driving software on cars in China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Some Concrete Reasons Not to Be Totally Panicked
description: And a few things we’d like to forget.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, I have a feeling we’re going to be spending a good amount of time talking about the adventures of Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Columbia Protests: The Musical
description: Students at the university staged “Mayday,” a show that satirizes the administration, especially the beleaguered president, Nemat Shafik.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at a musical satire by undergraduate students from Columbia and Barnard that took aim at university administrators. We’ll also find out how music therapy is helping some children in Brooklyn cope with the stress of homelessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Vivian Nereim and Emad Mekay
title: As Anger Grows Over Gaza, Arab Leaders Crack Down on Protests
description: Grief and rage over the war and Israel have led to demonstrations across the Arab world. Arrests suggest governments fear the outrage could boomerang.
content: Like other governments across the Middle East, Egypt has not been shy about its position on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Its denunciations of Israel over the war in Gaza are loud and constant. State media outlets broadcast images of long lines of aid trucks waiting to cross from Egypt into Gaza, spotlighting Egypt’s role as the main  conduit for aid entering the besieged territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Federal Agencies to Restore Grizzly Bears in Washington State
description: Grizzly bears haven’t been seen in the North Cascades range, where they were once a vital part of the ecosystem, in nearly 30 years.
content: The federal government plans to restore grizzly bears to the North Cascades range in northwestern Washington state, where they once roamed and were an essential part of the region’s ecosystem, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Kamala Harris Leads Push to Shore Up Democratic Support From Black Voters
description: Speaking in Atlanta, the vice president began a national tour to highlight how the Biden administration is trying to help Black Americans economically.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris made a new effort to energize Black voters in battleground states on Monday, visiting Atlanta for the kickoff of a national economic tour that will highlight how the Biden administration says its policies are helping a constituency that will be vital to Democrats’ success in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Hamed Aleaziz
title: Biden and Mexico’s President Vow Combined Action on Illegal Immigration
description: President Biden is under intense political pressure, including from within his own party, to address migration before the election.
content: President Biden and the president of Mexico on Monday vowed combined action to prevent illegal immigration as Mr. Biden remains under intense political pressure from all sides to address the impact of surging border crossings ahead of the presidential election this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Who Gains From Elon Musk’s Visit to China?
description: Tesla’s C.E.O. appears to have landed a deal that moves the company closer to bringing fully autonomous driving to a giant market. But Beijing is keen to exploit the visit for its own purposes.
content: Just days after Secretary of State Antony Blinken traveled to Beijing and warned China about unfair trade practices, Elon Musk landed in the Chinese capital. The Tesla boss’s meeting with China’s No. 2 official may have paid off: Musk reportedly cleared two obstacles to introducing a fully autonomous driving system in the world’s biggest car market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Surrounded by Fighters and Haunted by Famine, Sudan City Fears Worst
description: A powerful paramilitary group has encircled El Fasher, the last remaining obstacle to domination of the sprawling Darfur region, raising alarm about mass killings if the city is taken.
content: Fears of renewed ethnic slaughter in the Sudanese region of Darfur, where genocidal violence killed as many as 300,000 people two decades ago, have soared in recent days, with a looming assault on an embattled city that is already threatened by famine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: The latest push for a cease-fire in Gaza.
content: International diplomats converged yesterday on the Middle East to press for a cease-fire between Israel and Hamas as Israel wrestled with whether to begin a ground invasion of Rafah in southern Gaza, according to Israeli analysts and officials. The officials said that they were open to holding off on an invasion if it meant that Israeli hostages taken during the Oct. 7 attacks would be released.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb, Livia Albeck-Ripka, Eduardo Medina and Remy Tumin
title: 8 Officers Are Shot, 4 Fatally, While Serving Warrant in Charlotte
description: Three of the four were part of a U.S. Marshals task force. The felon whom they sought was also killed.
content: Eight law officers were shot on Monday, four fatally, as a U.S. Marshals fugitive task force tried to serve a warrant in Charlotte, N.C., the police said, in one of the deadliest days for law enforcement in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: How Did Black Forest Cake Become the World’s Favorite Dessert?
description: Dessert lovers from Chile to Pakistan to Fiji claim it as a national treat. How did it get there from the woods of Germany?
content: It’s a classic Trinidadian dessert — a chocolate cake soaked in overproof rum and topped with swoops of ultrapasteurized whipped cream.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Philippines Closes Schools as Heat Soars to ‘Danger’ Level
description: Scorching temperatures coincided with a nationwide strike of jeepneys, the main mode of public transport in the country.
content: The Philippines closed all public schools on Monday and Tuesday because of dangerously high temperatures, moving classes online in a country where schools are typically shut because of tropical storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Retreats From Villages on Eastern Front as It Awaits U.S. Aid
description: Ukraine’s top commander said his outgunned troops were facing a dire situation as Russia tried to push its advantage before the first batch of an American military package arrives.
content: Russian troops have captured or entered around a half-dozen villages on Ukraine’s eastern front over the past week, highlighting the deteriorating situation in the region for outgunned and outnumbered Ukrainian forces as they wait for long-needed American military aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Why an Immunity Ruling in Trump’s Favor Might Not Alter the Shape of His Trial
description: Prosecutors believe Donald J. Trump’s official acts in trying to overturn the election should be admissible evidence even if the Supreme Court rules they cannot be the basis of the charges.
content: If the Supreme Court rules that Donald J. Trump is immune from being charged with crimes over official actions he took as president, it would be a momentous decision for the future of executive power and American-style democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Humza Yousaf Resigns as Scotland’s First Minister
description: Mr. Yousaf, the leader of the Scottish National Party, announced that he was stepping down, days after the collapse of his coalition government.
content: Scotland’s first minister, Humza Yousaf, resigned on Monday in a fresh setback for his Scottish National Party, which has been engulfed in a slow-burning crisis over a funding scandal that erupted after a popular leader, Nicola Sturgeon, stepped down last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump Is Flirting With Quack Economics
description: Beware strongmen who engage in magical thinking.
content: More than 30 years ago, the economists Rudiger Dornbusch (one of my mentors) and Sebastian Edwards wrote a classic paper on what they called “macroeconomic populism.” Their motivating examples were inflationary outbreaks under left-wing regimes in Latin America, but it seemed clear that the key issue wasn’t left-wing governance per se; it was, instead, what happens when governments engage in magical thinking. Indeed, even at the time they could have included the experience of the military dictatorship that ruled Argentina from 1976 to 1983, which killed or “disappeared” thousands of leftists but also pursued irresponsible economic policies that led to a balance-of-payments crisis and soaring inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review No. 1,045
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Jong-Fast
title: When Your Mom Is Famous for Hating Motherhood
description: In Heidi Reimer’s debut novel, “The Mother Act,” a daughter grapples with being parented (or not) by an actress who happily mines her life for material.
content: Writing about one’s own children has always been a delicate matter. It’s itchy and complicated, and there is no right way to do it. As a child who was often a subject of the writing of my mother, Erica Jong (and sometimes my grandfather Howard Fast), I have very mixed feelings about the phenomenon. I like to think I truly hated being written about, but who can remember? Later, I found it gave me a profound lack of shame and no expectation of privacy, which helped me pursue a public-facing career I might otherwise not have. All of this is to say that as I read “The Mother Act,” I felt uncomfortably close to the topic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Karen Weise and Tripp Mickle
title: A.I. Start-Ups Face a Rough Financial Reality Check
description: The table stakes for small companies to compete with the likes of Microsoft and Google are in the billions of dollars. And even that may not be enough.
content: Call it the end of the beginning of the A.I. boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: How They Served the Tennis Scenes in ‘Challengers’
description: Painstaking effort went into building the energetic competition moments in Luca Guadagnino’s love-triangle tennis drama. Here’s a closer look at the process.
content: “Let’s not make a tennis film.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: A Smooth-Running Gallery Weekend Amid a Shaken Berlin Art Scene
description: The annual event brings art collectors to the city, but the spirit of freedom that draws artists there has been damaged by the fallout from the Oct. 7 attacks.
content: Berlin’s international reputation as a liberal, relaxed city that nurtures artists’ freedom to express whatever they want is under threat. The art scene here has been roiled by protests, cancellations and boycotts after the Oct. 7 attacks in southern Israel, and many artists now say that a climate of fear has replaced the city’s anything-goes vibe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Notice From Columbia Administrators
description: Students in the encampment were told they would be suspended if they did not leave before the deadline.
content: Students in the encampment were told they would be suspended if they did not leave before the deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden, Taylor Robinson, Leanne Abraham and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Where Third-Party and Independent Candidates Are On The Ballot
description: For presidential candidates who are not the Republican or Democratic Party nominee, getting on the ballot for the general election is a state-by-state, make-or-break scramble.
content: For presidential candidates who are not the Republican or Democratic Party nominee, getting on the ballot for the general election is a state-by-state, make-or-break scramble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Where in the West Do These Books Take Place?
description: Try this short quiz on novels, geography and history of the American West.
content: Try this short quiz on novels, geography and history of the American West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: The Book Review’s Best Books Since 2000
description: Looking for your next great read? We’ve got 3,228. Explore the best fiction and nonfiction from 2000 - 2023 chosen by our editors.
content: Looking for your next great read? We’ve got 3,228. Explore the best fiction and nonfiction from 2000 - 2023 chosen by our editors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Deadly Mudslides Hit Kenya After Weeks of Torrential Rain
description: Flash flooding sent a deluge of muddy water over an area in the Rift Valley region of southern Kenya.
content: Flash flooding sent a deluge of muddy water over an area in the Rift Valley region of southern Kenya.
source.name: The New York Times
